content:
The "National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government Act" establishes a commission with the duty to eliminate waste in government. The "National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government Act" establishes a commission tasked with conducting surveys on management and cost control in the Federal Government, reviewing agency operations, and analyzing recommendations for reducing waste. The commission will submit reports to the President and Congress with significant recommendations and estimated savings. The National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government Act establishes a commission to identify opportunities for increased efficiency, enhance managerial accountability, terminate specific federal programs, and improve program services through executive action or legislation. Recommendations will be submitted to the President and Congress for improving budget processes and reducing waste and costs in the Federal Government. The National Commission to Eliminate Waste in Government Act establishes a commission to identify opportunities for increased efficiency, terminate specific federal programs, and improve program services through executive action or legislation. Recommendations will be submitted to the President and Congress for improving budget processes, increasing accountability, and identifying areas for potential savings in the Federal Government. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by various political leaders, with a limit on the number from the same party. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by political leaders, with limits on party representation. Members serve for life, vacancies filled within 30 days, no compensation, quorum of five members required. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by political leaders with limits on party representation. Members serve for life, vacancies filled within 30 days, no compensation. A quorum of five members is required for hearings. The Chairperson is elected by the members and the Commission must meet at least once a month. The Commission's Director is appointed by the Chairperson and paid by the Commission. The Director can hire staff with Commission approval. The Commission is granted powers. The Commission, under SEC. 6, has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, delegate authority, obtain information from federal agencies, and enter into contracts for supplies or services. SEC. 7. REPORTS.

The Commission will issue periodic reports to the President and Congress as required. A final report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions must be submitted within 24 months of the Act's enactment.

SEC. 8. TERMINATION.

The Commission will terminate within 30 days of submitting the final report under section 7(b).

SEC. 9 FUNDING AND SUPPORT. The Commission will be funded, staffed, and equipped by the private sector at no cost to the Federal Government. The Secretary of Commerce will collaborate with a nonprofit organization to provide support for the Commission.
